awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The interaction of discourse status and memory retrieval in real time language processing
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation research project explores the cognitive underpinnings of how humans read and comprehend sentences. More specifically, the project will advance linguistic theories in semantics and pragmatics by investigating how different types of linguistic information in a discourse context are represented and processed. Results from this experimental investigation will inform our understanding of the interplay between working memory and language and psycholinguistics, and will  potentially be of use to fields such as behavioral marketing and journalism, where understanding one’s interpretation of rhetorical and discourse structure is of crucial importance.  The project will also enrich the co-PI’s mentoring and managerial skills, and will provide undergraduate assistants with valuable research experience.

The project is comprised of multiple sentence processing experiments that will manipulate relative clause types that differ in discourse status--appositive relative clauses (ARCs) and restrictive relative clauses (RRCs)--to investigate the organization and maintenance of discourse structure and information in working memory. Multiple methods (self-paced reading and eye tracking) are deployed to assess the impact of relative clause type on reading costs:  Number agreement attraction effects in ARC and RRC contexts are compared in Experiments 1–5; processing costs for subject- versus object-relative clauses are investigated in Experiments 6–7; and pronominal reference and presupposition resolution across ARCs and RRCs is examined in Experiments 8–11. Findings will contribute to the understanding of how discourse status impacts working memory retrieval in real-time language processing, and will also provide insight for advancing linguistic theories related to discourse structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Be it a congressional meeting or a causal conversation, some discourse information is more important and relevant to the topic than others. The current project aims to understand how this distinction---more vs. less important discourse status---is used during real-time language comprehension. The project investigates the way such distinction is used in working memory, specifically focusing on the encoding and retrieval process of discourse information of different status.

The experimental results show that both memory retrieval and encoding of linguistic information is constrained by discourse status. Memory retrieval for language comprehension has been known to be susceptible to interference, and the current findings show that such interference effect is affected by discourse status. The results also show that the memory architecture is sensitive to discourse status even when the status of linguistic information changes over time throughout incremental processing of language. The findings also show that the sensitivity to discourse status is modulated by the type of linguistic dependency. For example, resolving a subject-verb dependency and anaphoric dependency is exhibited in distinct ways depending on the discourse status of linguistic item. The results also show that overlap of discourse status between linguistic items lead to interference effect, even during the encoding process.
